title: How to Make Dishwasher Detergent Tabs

steps.headline: Combine equal amounts of washing soda and borax.
steps.description: You will need 2 cups (500 g) of washing soda and 2 cups (818 g) of borax. The washing soda will help eliminate grease, while the borax will help disinfect the dishes. If you cannot find washing soda, you can try using baking soda.

steps.headline: Add 1/2 cup (150 g) of salt and 15 to 20 drops of lemon essential oil.
steps.description: Give all of your ingredients a quick stir at this point. The salt will help soften hard water, while the lemon essential oil will help eliminate bacteria. It will also give your tabs a fresh scent. Try to use kosher salt, if you can. If you cannot find any, use sea salt instead.

steps.headline: Stir in 1/2 cup (120 mL) of white vinegar.
steps.description: The vinegar will cause the mixture to fizz, which is normal. Wait for the mixture to stop fizzing, then give it a stir. It should become damp and clumpy, like wet sand. White vinegar will help disinfect your dishes.

steps.headline: Pack the mixture into ice cube trays.
steps.description: You can also use a small, silicone baking mold, as long as the cavities are the same size at the detergent well in your dishwasher. Plan on using about 1 tablespoon of the mixture per cavity.

steps.headline: Let the mixture dry for at least 24 hours.
steps.description: Leave the mixture in a dry location where they won't be bumped. A spot on a sunny porch would be ideal, but you can keep them indoors as well. The mixture will become hard as it dries.

steps.headline: Remove the tabs from the ice cube tray.
steps.description: Twist the ice cube tray to loosen the tabs, then carefully turn the tray over onto a paper towel. The tabs should slide out easily. If they don't come out easily, then they are not completely dry; leave the tray out in the sun for another 12 to 24 hours.

steps.headline: Use one tab in the detergent compartment of your dishwasher.
steps.description: Pour 1/2 to 1 cup (120 to 240 mL) of white vinegar into the bottom of your dishwasher, then close your dishwasher and start a cycle. The vinegar here will help further disinfect your dishes as well as reduce clouding caused by hard water. If you want to give your tabs a little extra cleaning power, add one to three drops of dish detergent to the compartment as well. Store the rest of the tabs in a glass jar, in a cool, dry location.

steps.headline: Combine equal amounts of washing soda, kosher salt, and baking soda.
steps.description: Pour 1 cup (250 g) of washing soda into a bowl. This is your main cleaning again. Add 1 cup (300 g) of kosher salt to reduce hard water buildup, and 1 cup (180 g) of baking soda to cut the grease. Stir everything together with a spoon. If you live in an area with soft water, you can use less kosher salt.

steps.headline: Add 3/4 cup (180 mL) of lemon juice.
steps.description: This will help get those dishes clean as well as eliminate bacteria. It will also give your dishes a fresh scent. The lemon juice will cause the ingredients to fizz up, so wait for the fizz to die down. If you do not have that much lemon juice, use three packets of unsweetened lemonade drink mix and 1 cup (240mL) of water.

steps.headline: Stir the mixture together.
steps.description: Once the fizzing has stopped, stir everything together with a spoon until the mixture is evenly damp and no dry spots remain. It should clump together, sort of like wet sand.

steps.headline: Pack the mixture into your desired molds.
steps.description: Ice cube trays work great for this, but you can use mini muffin tins or small silicone baking molds. Make sure that the cavities in your mold are smaller than the detergent compartment of your dishwasher. Plan on using about 1 tablespoon of the mixture per cavity.

steps.headline: Wait 12 to 24 hours for the tabs to harden.
steps.description: Leave the molds in a warm, dry location for 12 to 24 hours. Do not bump, touch, or mess with them during this time. The tabs will harden as they dry.

steps.headline: Pop the tabs out of the molds and store them in an airtight container.
steps.description: Once the tabs are dry, turn the mold over onto a paper towel; you may have to twist it in order to get the tabs out. If the tabs don't come out easily, they are probably not completely dry. Leave them in the tray for another 12 to 24 hours before trying again.

steps.headline: Use one tab in the detergent compartment.
steps.description: Load your dishwasher and place one tab into the detergent compartment. Close the dishwasher, then start a cycle. Keep the rest of the tabs in a cool, dry location; a glass jar will be the best.

steps.headline: Mix together your washing soda, baking soda, citric acid, and salt.
steps.description: Pour 2 cups (500 g) of washing soda into a big bowl. Add 1 cup (180 g) of baking soda, 1 cup (300 g) of citric acid, and 1 cup (300 g) of kosher salt.

steps.headline: Stir in 30 drops each of lemon essential oil and lavender essential oil.
steps.description: The lemon essential oil has antibacterial and disinfecting properties. The lavender essential oil will also lend your tabs extra disinfecting power. Keep stirring until the oils are evenly distributed throughout the mixture. If you cannot find lavender essential oil, or do not like the smell, use tea tree essential oil instead. Make sure that you use pure essential oil and not fragrance oil used in soap or candle making.

steps.headline: Add 1 cup (225 g) of oxygen bleach.
steps.description: This will help clean up tough stains. Do not use regular liquid bleach. Use a product that is labeled "oxygen bleach," such as Oxyclean. It comes in a powder.

steps.headline: Stir in 2 to 4 tablespoons (30 to 60 mL) of filtered water.
steps.description: Start with 1 tablespoon (15 mL) of water. Give the mixture a stir, then wait for the fizzing to stop. The mixture should be wet enough to just hold together when squeezed in your fist. If the mixture does not do that, add the rest of the water, 1 tablespoon (15 mL) at a time. You may not end up using all of the water. Do not make the mixture too wet and soggy, or the ingredients will overreact and not work properly.

steps.headline: Pack the mixture into your desired molds.
steps.description: Ice cube trays, mini muffin tins, and silicone backing molds all work well for this. Make sure that the cavities are smaller than the detergent compartment in your dishwasher, otherwise the tabs will be too big. Plan on using about 1 tablespoon per cavity.

steps.headline: Allow the tabs to dry for 12 to 24 hours.
steps.description: Set the trays someplace warm and dry where they will not be accidentally bumped or knocked over. Let them sit for 12 to 24 hours, or until they are completely dry.

steps.headline: Remove the tabs from the molds.
steps.description: Turn the mold over onto a paper towel, then twist or wiggle it to loosen the tabs. If the tabs do not come out, it is because they are not fully dry. Leave them in the same warm, dry spot for another 12 to 24 hours.

steps.headline: Use one tab per load in your dishwasher.
steps.description: Place one tab into the detergent compartment of your dishwasher. Close the dishwasher and start a cycle. Store the rest of the tabs in a cool, dry location, preferably in a glass jar.
